title: Copy job generator
author: Author
batchXcopyOptions-w: Displays the following message and waits for your response before starting to copy files: Press any key to begin copying file(s)
batchXcopyOptions-p: Prompts you to confirm whether you want to create each destination file.
batchXcopyOptions-v: Verifies each file as it is written to the destination file to make sure that the destination files are identical to the source files.
batchXcopyOptions-q: Suppresses the display of xcopy messages.
batchXcopyOptions-f: Displays source and destination file names while copying.
batchXcopyOptions-l: Displays a list of files that are to be copied.
batchXcopyOptions-g: Creates decrypted Destination files when the destination does not support encryption.
batchXcopyOptions-d: Copies source files changed on or after the specified date only. If you do not include a MM-DD-YYYY value, xcopy copies all Source files that are newer than existing Destination files. This command-line option allows you to update files that have changed.
batchXcopyOptions-u: Copies files from Source that exist on Destination only.
batchXcopyOptions-i: If Source is a directory or contains wildcards and Destination does not exist, xcopy assumes Destination specifies a directory name and creates a new directory. Then, xcopy copies all specified files into the new directory. By default, xcopy prompts you to specify whether Destination is a file or a directory.
batchXcopyOptions-s: Copies directories and subdirectories, unless they are empty. If you omit /s, xcopy works within a single directory.
batchXcopyOptions-e: Copies all subdirectories, even if they are empty. Use /e with the /s and /t command-line options.
batchXcopyOptions-t: Copies the subdirectory structure (that is, the tree) only, not files. To copy empty directories, you must include the /e command-line option.
